Frontend.name: JavaScript
Frontend.info: Javascript is a programming language I have used in every web application project and can confidently say I'm well experienced using it. The reason for this rating is because Javascript is so vast and there is a lot more to learn

Frontend.name: React
Frontend.info: I have used React in several projects and can work with it comfortably. I am confident building components and managing state effectively.

Frontend.name: React Native
Frontend.info: I am familiar with React Native for mobile development. Since it shares many concepts with React, I am confident I can pick it up quickly for new projects.

Frontend.name: Vue.js
Frontend.info: I have used Vue.js in various projects and have written front-end test cases using Vue Jest. I have also worked with frameworks like Vuetify to improve user experience.

Frontend.name: Tailwind CSS
Frontend.info: Using Tailwind CSS I was able to make this portfolio website more responsive and polished. Next to this I have applied Tailwind in several projects and understand its core concepts.

Frontend.name: Bootstrap
Frontend.info: I have used Bootstrap in projects before attending HvA. I am familiar with it, but I haven’t applied it extensively in recent work.

Backend.name: Python
Backend.info: Python is the language I have used most recently for building applications, backends, and exploring artificial intelligence. I am comfortable using Python for a variety of tasks.

Backend.name: Java
Backend.info: I have used Java to build backends with Spring Boot, as well as object-oriented applications for school assignments. This allowed me to learn the basics of encapsulation, inheritance, polymorphism and abstraction.

Backend.name: Node.js
Backend.info: With Node.js I have built server-side applications and APIs, focusing on asynchronous programming and efficient request handling.

Backend.name: PHP
Backend.info: I have experience with PHP in legacy projects and simple web applications. I am familiar with the language, though I haven’t used it in recent projects.

Frameworks.name: Spring Boot
Frameworks.info: I have used Spring Boot in Java projects to build RESTful APIs and backend services. This application also uses Spring Boot Java to connect to the database and create API endpoints.

Frameworks.name: Express.js
Frameworks.info: I have used Express.js during group projects where I had to make use of Express.js in order to use the backend but was not responsible for setting up the service.

Frameworks.name: Django
Frameworks.info: Django is a very beginner friendly framework and was very easy to get into. This combined with python being the backbone leaned me to use it for multiple full-stack projects and allowing me to learn how to use the framework with relative ease.

Frameworks.name: FastAPI
Frameworks.info: FastAPI is a modern Python framework for building APIs. I have used it for individual assignments to quickly create full-stack applications and experiment with API development.

Databases.name: MySQL / MariaDB - SQL
Databases.info: I have used primarily MySQL and MariaDB for storing data, relational database design, writing queries, and managing schemas. I am comfortable creating tables, defining relationships, and performing CRUD operations.

Databases.name: PostgreSQL - SQL
Databases.info: PostgreSQL shares many similarities to MySQL and MariaDB. I have applied PostgreSQL to fewer project but am confident managing databases with it. This project also makes use of PostgreSQL for CRUD operations.

Databases.name: MongoDB - NoSQL
Databases.info: While having not directly applied MongoDB to any large scale projects. I am familiar using NoSQL and MongoDB from assignments where the goal was to store/retrieve unstructured data and use aggregation and collections.

Databases.name: Data modeling & ER diagrams
Databases.info: Using tools such as MySQLWorkbench in many of my project to create data models and ER diagrams for planning database structures. This helps in understanding relationships and optimizing database design before implementation, as well as reverse engineering diagrams into database tables.

Other.name: Git
Other.info: Using Git for version control, branching, merging and code reviews making it a staple in my development workflow. Also by making use of webhooks I can automate the deployment in projects such as this Raspberry Pi website.

Other.name: Docker
Other.info: I have experience using Docker to containerize applications for consistent development. I have applied it in multiple projects and internships. I can write Dockerfiles and use Docker Compose for multi-container projects.

Other.name: AWS
Other.info: My experience with AWS is limited to a single project during a minor in Cloud Solutions which took half a year. I am familiar with AWS services such as S3, EC2, Lambdas, RDS and understand the fundamentals of cloud computing.

Other.name: Linux
Other.info: I have used linux very little during my education. Most of my experience comes from tinkering with my raspberry which has a Linux Debian OS installed. I would not say that im very experienced but I am familiar with navigating Linux terminals, using commands for file management and basic shell scripting for automation tasks.

Other.name: Agile work methods
Other.info: In my team projects, I have applied both Waterfall and Scrum methodologies. This allowed me to learn which steps to take in order the plan and finish a project successfully.

Other.name: AI technology
Other.info: In recent years I have been studying and experimenting AI technologies due to their rapid developement and capabilties. I have created and trained small machine-learning and deep-learning algorithms as well as apply them during internships. This allowed me to learn how the process of an AI models works and what uses they could have.
